Everything we create, everything we do, it all starts with our thinking

Clear thinking drastically improves odds of success in all departments of career & life

While clear thinking is quite rare, it can be developed with practice

Advanced principles for clear thinking:

(1/12)
1) Essence first. Not story. Not analogy

Most people get seduced by great analogies & exciting stories.

Clear thinkers don’t *form* their thinking via analogies. They identify the essence of the issue, in their specific context. Then, they use analogies as one of their inputs.
2) WAYRTTD

“What Are You _Really_ Trying To Do” is a simple but powerful tool to make you pause & identify your real goal

Most people move too quickly to How & When to do a given task.  But the task isn’t the goal

Clear thinkers have built a habit of asking themselves WAYRTTD.
3) Message vs. Messenger

Most people first evaluate the messenger & they don’t evaluate the message enough. The apparent superior/inferior status of the messenger clouds their thinking.

Clear thinkers practice their best to evaluate the message separately from the messenger.
4) Tough to communicate

When dealing with close choices, most people pick the choice that is less stressful to communicate & reject the choice that will seemingly require a tough conversation

Clear thinkers resist this bias & communicate the correct choice as kindly as possible
5) Probabilistic thinking

Most people think in terms of “X will happen” “Y will not happen”. They live in the jail of binary thinking

Clear thinkers see the future as probabilistic. They think in terms of approximate probability that X will/won't happen & decide/act accordingly
6) Start with principles

When choosing between X & Y, most people list pros & cons for X & Y and then try to decide

To think more clearly, start with principles/goals you care about. Stack rank them. Now you can decide more confidently between X, Y & any new options that emerge
7) Think one level higher

Most people only think at the level they are currently at within the organization.

While this is a fine default, clear thinkers create a habit of also thinking one level higher. They assess what might make sense at that level, to inform their thinking.
8) Metacognition

Most people don’t understand much about why they think & feel what they think & feel. They are mere passengers on their own train of thought.

Clear thinkers develop a habit of observing their own thinking, analyzing it with curiosity & adapting it accordingly.
9) Opportunity cost

Most people decide what to work on solely by ROI.

ROI = (Value created – Cost of your time) ÷ Cost of your time

For decisions that matter greatly, clear thinkers consider Opportunity Cost.

Opportunity Cost = Value of optimal option – Value of chosen option
10) Ownership mindset

Most people’s thinking gets clouded by all sorts of noise & drama in their environment.

Clear thinkers approach whatever they choose to work on with an ownership mindset. So they are more focused on the greater goal and they adopt a collaborative approach.
11) Control over ego

Most people attach their identity to their ideas & thinking. This makes it hard for them to adapt their thinking & see reality as it is

Clear thinkers are not immune to the ego, but they are able to control it enough so they can iterate towards correctness.
12) Antithesis principle

Most people love consistency. So they assume any truth they observe in the world must also apply to them

Clear thinkers know that at times you must adopt the antithesis of that truth to yourself so you can be a wiser, happier, effective person yourself.

Some thoughts on Individual Contributor (IC) vs. Manager paths in product management:

1) The manager path isn’t the “evil path”. The IC path isn’t the “loser’s path”

2) Early/mid-level PM Managers need to mostly exercise core PM skills, just at greater scope & throughput
3) So early on, fixate on the goal of building core competence, not the goal of “managing PMs”

4) Try being a PM manager at least a couple of times before you decide it is not for you. You might hate it early on, but you might just surprise yourself with how much you love it
5) Plus, there is probably a good reason why your company is pushing you to become a PM manager (while others who badly want to be PM managers are not getting the role)
6) To be an effective PM manager, the first thing you will need to begin shedding is pride in your IC PM skills, because that pride will make you an intolerable manager for your PMs
7) If you decide that IC is the right path for you long-term, make sure that you are committed to becoming a top 10% IC PM over time. Reason is that that will keep you relevant, employed, and in-demand regardless of the state of the economy
8) You will need to continue doing on your own “IC projects” for a bit, as a Sr. PM / GPM, sometimes even as a Director. While that is stressful, this is actually a good thing. It keeps you grounded in real problems (vs. theory) and helps you build more empathy
9) If after trying the manager path a few times you still decide that IC is what you want to do, that’s fine. There is also no shame in oscillating between IC and manager (I have done it 5 times total)
10) If you decide that SVP / CPO is not for you, again, no shame in that. Master the core skills that are necessary for Directors / VPs, and you will still be in demand by the fastest growing companies. You can still do very well compensation-wise. Not everyone has to become CPO
11) Whatever you do, try to resist the tendency to make inauthentic career moves due to LinkedIn envy and what signals virtue on Twitter. Do what works for you, your skills, your ambition, and your life situation. And to do that well, build greater self-awareness and maturity
Easier said than done, but surely can be done.

A really important concept to understand in work & life: the Antithesis Principle.

It is best explained through some examples, so that’s where I will start this thread.

(1/18)
First example.

Observation:

Most people learn better when the content / teaching is entertaining. 

Many people *only* learn if the content is entertaining.
As a smart & ambitious person, if you think *deeply* about what you should take away from this observation, you have to conclude the 2 things:

1) If you want to help people learn something, look into making it engaging / entertaining

This is the easier, more obvious conclusion.
2) It is actually not in *your* best interest to be the kind of person who can *only* learn from entertaining content. Nor to be the kind of person that needs any sort of entertainment as a prerequisite for learning.

90% of smart people will never consider this conclusion.
If you can be a person who does not need to be entertained very much (or at all) to learn, you will learn more things & different things than someone else who absolutely needs to be entertained for learning.

They will discard the profound book with a boring title, but you won’t.
This is not an isolated example. The Antithesis Principle is more widely applicable than might first be apparent. Let’s look at another example.
2nd example.

Observation:

A charismatic person will almost always influence people a lot more than a similarly capable uncharismatic person will. 

A charismatic person will usually even influence people a lot more than a much more capable uncharismatic person will.
What you should conclude from this

1) To grow your influence as a leader, it is better for you learn the art of charisma (the obvious conclusion)

2) To be wiser, it is in your best interest to work towards not being swayed by other people’s charisma (the non-obvious conclusion)
Now, most smart people think that they don’t get swayed by charisma. But most of them are wrong. They do get swayed by charisma all the time. They just don’t like to think that (because accepting that would contradict their self-image of being a smart person).

Smart ≠ Wise
3rd example.

I am sure you’ve heard at some point in your life that “Within the first 7 seconds of meeting you, people form a solid impression of who you are”. 

Now, who knows if it is actually true, but let’s assume for a moment that it is true.
What you should conclude

1) To be effective, you should consciously try to create a good 1st impression on other people (obvious)

2) It is in your best interest to work towards not being a person who forms a fixed impression of someone based on the first 7 seconds (non-obvious)
4th example

Everyone talks about how a great manager is so important. Tweet out “Only work for great managers” & you’re sure to get hundreds of likes & retweets. But reality is different from Twitter.

Yes, a manager is important, but let’s apply the Antithesis principle here.
To make a big impact

1) you should try to be a competent manager so you can help people do really good work (obvious conclusion)

2) you should turn yourself into a person who does really good work even when you report to an OK/absentee manager yourself (not obvious conclusion)
Why can’t most people deal with the Antithesis Principle?

Two reasons:
1) People love consistency. The Antithesis Principle creates inconsistency. Most people cannot process inconsistency.

2) People don't question their default programming. And when other people are programmed similarly, that's great validation for them to stay with the defaults.
So, here’s the Antithesis Principle:

You might need to understand a certain thing about how the world works & apply it, so you can be effective.

But you may need to adopt the antithesis of that to yourself so you can be a wiser, kinder, happier, more effective person yourself.
Armed with this context, you will find the Antithesis Principle in all sorts of places.

Take the idea that people love analogies. The Antithesis Principle says that you should explain by analogy (to help people understand) but not reason by analogy (to make yourself understand).
It applies to so many situations

So keep the Antithesis Principle in the back of your mind next time you make an observation about the world around you. You will not only reach the obvious conclusion that everyone reaches but also the non-obvious conclusion that very few reach.

The biggest problem with saying that Execution is more important than Ideas is that it demonstrates a gross misunderstanding of how you get outstanding Execution: you get it through 100s of excellent (and usually correct) Ideas about what to do & how to do it, day in and day out.
To elaborate:
The notion of That One Great Idea is silly. Think of Idea in plural form, not singular. It is not just the Ah-ha Archimedes Lighbulb moment. In the real world, to make any product spectacular, that moment must actually be followed by countless other ideas & choices.
These are ideas about how to solve problems, what compromises to make & not make, how to deal with people issues, how to tackle constraints, how to creatively organize & sequence work, how to set the right targets & goals, and on & on.

Ideas (plural) drive outstanding Execution.
That is why people who are consistently great at Execution tend to be very creative people who are Idea machines (note 2 things here: the converse isn’t necessarily true, and we are talking about great Execution not just good Execution)

Watch this please:
https://t.co/6LguwtvD8J
So overall, it is a fallacy to think about it as:

Idea → Execution → Success

Because great Execution isn't just about creating plans, updating spreadsheets, aligning resources, working hard, having courage, etc—all that by itself will just give you decent Execution, not great
Reality looks a bit like this:

Big Idea → Execute → Problem → Idea → Execute → Next Problem → Idea → Execute → Backtrack → Idea → Existential Problem → Idea → Idea → Idea → Execute → Surprise/Disappointment → Idea → Execute → Success → Next Problem and on & on
Lastly, one must remember the importance of a team. The products we love and use daily are made by teams, not 1 person. A team with outstanding execution needs people with great ideas, great taste, great grit, great discipline, etc. This need not be just 1 person (and never is).
Most would agree that Steve Jobs was great at execution. But Steve Jobs did not make everything with his own bare hands. He had 100s to 1000s of people around him. Some great at doing, but not coming up with great ideas. Others the opposite. Others were both. Team, not 1 person.

In the real world, to make any product spectacular, that moment must actually be followed by countless other ideas & choices.
These are ideas about how to solve problems, what compromises to make & not make, how to deal with people issues, how to tackle constraints, how to creatively organize & sequence work, how to set the right targets & goals, and on & on.

Ideas (plural) drive outstanding Execution.
That is why people who are consistently great at Execution tend to be very creative people who are Idea machines (note 2 things here: the converse isn’t necessarily true, and we are talking about great Execution not just good Execution)

Watch this please:
https://t.co/6LguwtvD8J
So overall, it is a fallacy to think about it as:

Idea → Execution → Success

Because great Execution isn't just about creating plans, updating spreadsheets, aligning resources, working hard, having courage, etc—all that by itself will just give you decent Execution, not great
Reality looks a bit like this:

Big Idea → Execute → Problem → Idea → Execute → Next Problem → Idea → Execute → Backtrack → Idea → Existential Problem → Idea → Idea → Idea → Execute → Surprise/Disappointment → Idea → Execute → Success → Next Problem and on & on
Lastly, one must remember the importance of a team.

The products we love and use daily are made by teams, not 1 person. A team with outstanding execution needs people with great ideas, great taste, great grit, great discipline, etc. This need not be just 1 person (and never is).
Most would agree that Steve Jobs was great at execution. But Steve Jobs did not make everything with his own bare hands. He had 100s to 1000s of people around him. Some great at doing, but not coming up with great ideas. Others the opposite. Others were both. Team, not 1 person.

essays.content:
One huge mistake that many managers make is to tell a senior member of their team:

“<XYZ> is entirely your decision. I am here to serve you. I will defer to whatever your decision is here.”

This happens at all levels e.g. a Founder/CEO delegating “product strategy” to the CPO.
By saying this, they are trying to be a “good manager”. But then, to be a “good leader” for the company, to make the company-optimal decision, they often overturn this team member’s decision. This causes a lot of confusion for everyone & major frustration for said team member.
The best managers avoid this trap. They avoid saying “XYZ is entirely your call.” They clarify what they care about most, what concerns them most. They provide guidelines for how said decision should be made, how they would weigh the trade-offs involved.
They also clarify what aspects of the decision they are completely delegating to the team member, what aspects they would like to review before a decision is made, and what aspects they would like to own instead of the team member. And they clarify the why behind each of these.
They do all this from a position of strength, not guilt. They make clear that ultimately the job is to optimize for the company that has put them in a leadership role.
They understand that soundbites might sound good in the short term, but what actually matters to their team members is clarity of responsibilities, sound decision making, and the real impact that will hopefully follow from this.

Listening and thinking actually don’t go well together. Your job as a listener is to consume in a few seconds / minutes what the speaker might have experienced over weeks / months / decades. So, as a listener, odds are stacked heavily against you.

What can you do about this?
👇🏾
Partition listening & thinking.

View them as phases or modes, not concurrent activities. When you are in listening mode, just be in listening mode. Just absorb. Don’t judge, don’t filter, don’t be overcome by emotions. This is not easy, but I have found it to be very powerful.
Then, once listening mode is over, get into thinking mode. At this point, I ask the speaker if I can think for a few seconds or a minute. I am now in pure thinking mode. This is when I evaluate, synthesize with my experience & viewpoints. And I frame my response.

Then, I speak.
This is sometimes awkward, especially when I am speaking with someone for the first time. But this awkwardness usually dissipates once they see

a) the degree to which I have absorbed their message

b) the quality of my response

Maybe not for everyone, but worth a try for some.

If you work in a company with many 100s or 1000s of employees, the best networking strategy actually lies in plain sight within your company.

Here’s how it works:
Ask trusted colleagues to name 5 people they know are *really* great in your company. Reach out to them with a friendly message. Not everyone will be able to respond, but usually 4 out 5 of them will. Share what you work on, learn about their work, build rapport, get to know them
You can do this even if you are very busy. For example, start by allocating 1 hour a month to this (that’s just 0.6% of your monthly hours). Plus, you will find this makes you better at your work (broader knowledge of the company / different roles / hiring within the company ...)
This is simple, but most people (99%?) completely squander this opportunity. I squandered it at most places I worked at. My biggest regret is not doing this when I was at Google (2008-2014). But I am glad I fixed it later in my career.

Try it out. You will likely not regret it.

Pretty much all best practices for creating group experiences (events, meetings, offsites, etc.) are exclusively catered to the preferences of extroverts. The introverts in these settings feel like they must just play along (mainly because they feel they _should_ be enjoying it).

essays.content:
New product initiatives within already-successful companies often fail to achieve their potential because they have too much rather than too little.

Too much of:

1) headcount: you are now under pressure to come up _something_ for all these people to do

👇🏾
2) democratic decision making: creative product ideas usually get killed (or watered down) by groups of people

3) optics requirements: need to manufacture metrics & milestones to *show* straight-line progress and demonstrate certainty during an inherently uncertain journey
4) involvement of the “core” product group: you have to make tremendous compromises within your new product to keep the leaders of the company’s core product happy
5) reliance on the company’s distribution: you and your team don’t have the incentive to understand the customers of your new product well-enough, and your initial traction is often misleading
So if you are leading a new initiative within a larger company and your CEO/CxO asks you what you need to succeed, do not default to the answer that everyone in this situation gives: “I need more resources”.
Instead, consider if you should be asking for less: less reporting, less certainty, less consensus-driven decision making, less meddling, and less pressure to build out a “full team” early on.

(clearly, this is only for the really intrepid product leaders, not for everyone 🙂)

Within a writing culture, your effectiveness (and hence your career growth) will partly depend on your writing ability.

If you want to improve your writing, one of your best bets is to ask a colleague who writes well to walk you through a few of their favorite documents.
People who write well and think positive sum are happy to show you all the nuances: here’s why I chose this structure, here’s why I didn’t follow the standard template, here are my favorite parts I had to nix.

Problem is many PMs never ask their colleagues for this type of help.
